title: 115_s62
content: The Act may be cited as the "January 8th National Memorial Act" and includes findings. The tragedy on January 8, 2011, at Congresswoman Gabrielle Gifford's event resulted in the deaths of 6 people and injuries to 13 others, including Giffords herself. It was the first assassination attempt on a Congressional Member during a public event. Giffords sustained severe injuries, and Gabe Zimmerman was the first Congressional staffer to be assassinated in the line of duty. The Arizona community and people worldwide came together in the aftermath of the tragedy. The world united after the tragedy on January 8, 2011, to provide comfort and support at three memorial sites in Tucson. The January 8th Memorial will honor the victims and showcase the community's resilience and democracy's strength in the United States. The January 8th National Memorial will honor the victims of the tragedy in Tucson and highlight the community's resilience and democracy's strength in the United States. The January 8th National Memorial, established by the Secretary of the Interior, will be affiliated with the National Park System once the Foundation complies with requirements. The Foundation has established a trust fund for receiving donations and managing the construction, operation, and maintenance of the Memorial. The Memorial will be managed by the Foundation and will cease to be affiliated with the National Park System if certain conditions are not met. The National Park Service will have the map of the Memorial available for public inspection. The Secretary can provide technical assistance and enter into cooperative agreements with the Foundation for financial assistance with marketing. The Secretary is limited in acquiring property or using Federal funds for the Memorial's construction, operation, maintenance, or management. A general management plan for the Memorial will be developed by the Secretary in consultation with the Foundation. The Secretary must provide a copy of the completed general management plan for the Memorial to the House Committee on Natural Resources and the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources within 3 years of funds being available for the Act or the Memorial's establishment.
